courseTitle: DNA Replication, RNA Transcription, and Protein Synthesis (Dry Lab)

pageData.titleName2: DNA Replication, RNA Transcription, and Protein Synthesis

pageData.text: In this laboratory investigation, students explore the basic structure of and (RNA) molecules while modeling the process of . Then, students will investigate the processing of genetic information via and . Finally, students examine the processes and consequences of genetic mutations.

text: Describe the general structure of DNA and RNA.
Design a simulation of a model showing the replication of DNA and RNA.
Create models in a simulation demonstrating and .
Identify causes of genetic mutations and their effect on protein synthesis.

pageData.text: Genetic disorders occur when a mutation occurs in a <button class='glossary-text'>gene</button>. Many of these disorders are inherited, such as sickle-cell or hemophilia. Exposure to chemicals, pollutants, and radiation can also cause genetic mutations that are associated with chronic diseases and cancer. However, mutations are not always bad.

One of the genes involved in maintaining bone density in human beings is called low-density lipoprotein receptor-related protein 5 (LRP5). Certain mutations impair the function of LRP5 and are associated with osteoporosis (low bone density), but a different kind of mutation in LRP5 can increase its function and result in higher levels of bone density. This mutation was discovered after a young person was in a terrible car accident but walked away from it. After the crash, researchers studied the family and discovered that no one in the family had ever broken a bone and had much higher-than-average bone density. The only negative side effect appears to be that some of the family members with the mutation have boney growths in the roof of their mouths1. Researchers are currently working on gene therapies that may enhance the function of LRP5 and prevent osteoporosis.1Boyden, L. M., Mao, J., Belsky, J., Mitzner, L., Farhi, A., Mitnick, M. A., Wu, D., Insogna, K., & Lifton, R. P. (2002). High bone density due to a mutation in LDL-receptor-related protein 5. The New England journal of medicine, 346(20), 1513–1521. https://doi.org/10.1056/NEJMoa013444

pageData.altText: A medical illustration of a bone cross section.
pageData.desc: A medical illustration of a bone cross section.

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA)</button> stores the genetic information in all living cells. The inheritable characteristics and processes of living organisms are encoded within the <button class='glossary-text'>nucleotide</button> order of their DNA molecules. DNA takes the form of a double helix (resembling a twisted ladder). A DNA molecule has two complementary strands made up of nitrogenous bases, sugars (represented by "S" in Figure 1), and phosphates (represented by “P” in Figure 1). The four bases found in DNA are the two purines, <button class='glossary-text'>adenine</button> (A) and <button class='glossary-text'>guanine</button> (G), and the two pyrimidines, <button class='glossary-text'>cytosine</button> (C) and <button class='glossary-text'>thymine</button> (T). These bases follow the base-pairing rules discovered by DNA pioneers James Watson and Francis Crick: adenine and thymine always pair together with two hydrogen bonds, and guanine and cytosine always pair together with three hydrogen bonds (Figure 1).

pageData.altText: Figure 1: A diagram of a DNA molecule shows two strands twisted around each other. Each strand is an alternating sequence of sugars and phosphate groups, with a base attached to each sugar. The bases orient toward each other and form specific pairs. A pairs with T, and G pairs with C.

pageData.text: DNA contains the five-carbon sugar deoxyribose. RNA contains the five-carbon sugar ribose. Understanding how the carbons within these sugar molecules are numbered is essential to understanding nucleic acid formation and orientation. Each carbon is assigned a number, 1–5. Deoxyribose is shown in Figure 2, with each carbon numbered.

pageData.altText: Figure 2: Deoxyribose is a five-membered ring. One oxygen atom and four carbon atoms make up the ring. The carbon atoms are numbered clockwise from the oxygen atom. Carbons one prime, two prime, three prime, and four prime make up the rest of the ring. Carbon five prime extends from carbon four prime, and is not part of the ring. Each carbon atom, except for carbon two prime, has an attached O H group.

pageData.text: In a nucleotide, the phosphate group is bound to the 5’ (pronounced “five prime”) carbon of the sugar molecule, and the nitrogenous base is bound to the 1' carbon of the sugar molecule. To form nucleic acid chains, nucleotides form covalent bonds between the phosphate group of one nucleotide and the 3’ carbon of the sugar molecule of another nucleotide. This forms the phosphate-sugar backbone of a nucleic acid strand. In DNA, the two oppositely aligned backbone strands are described as being antiparallel. At the end, or terminus, of a double-stranded DNA molecule, one strand will expose its 5’ phosphate end and the other will expose its 3’ unbound hydroxyl (-OH) end.

pageData.question: In DNA, which of the following base pairs is most likely to form?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: In DNA, the nucleotide bases follow the base-pairing rules: adenine (A) and thymine (T) always pair together with two hydrogen bonds, and guanine (G) and cytosine (C) always pair together with three hydrogen bonds.

pageData.question: Which of the following does the shape of a DNA double helix resemble?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: A double helix resembles a twisted ladder.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The inheritable characteristics and processes of living organisms are encoded within the nucleotide order of their DNA molecules. In multicellular organisms (eukaryotes), DNA is arranged in the form of a double helix, with two complementary strands made up of nucleotide bases, sugars, and phosphates. The four nucleic acids found in DNA are the two purines, adenine (A) and guanine (G), and the two pyrimidines, cytosine (C) and thymine (T).

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The inheritable characteristics and processes of living organisms are encoded within the nucleotide order of their DNA molecules. In multicellular organisms (eukaryotes), DNA is arranged in the form of a double helix, with two complementary strands made up of nucleotide bases, sugars, and phosphates. The four nucleic acids found in DNA are the two purines, adenine (A) and guanine (G), and the two pyrimidines, cytosine (C) and thymine (T).

pageData.subTitle: DNA Replication
pageData.text: All the genetic information is grouped into which are located on chromosomes. Humans have 23 pairs of chromosomes. DNA is the carrier of genetic information. Because of this, it is essential that the sequence be correctly duplicated from one cell division to the next. This process is known as . During the process of replication, the two complementary strands of DNA are partly denatured, or separated, by the action of proteins called . Each DNA strand then utilizes special enzymes to complete the synthesis of a complementary strand by base pairing.

The process of replicating the genetic information in the cell followed by duplication of the cell is know as . Before mitosis occurs there are distinct stages which aid in duplication and checking the DNA for errors (Figure 3). Damage in the DNA code can lead to mistranslations of the code and result in nonfunctional proteins which can lead to diseases. Therefore, it is very important to reduce or correct errors in the DNA due to damage.

At the G1 checkpoint, proteins check for DNA damage. In the event of damage detection, chemical pathways are triggered, which inhibit the activation of proteins that advance the cell into S-phase. If no damage is detected, then the cell proceeds past the restriction point and the cell will enter S-phase, during which the DNA is replicated. During the G2-phase, the second regulatory checkpoint, the G2 checkpoint occurs. The replicated DNA is checked for errors, and the quantity of proteins is monitored. If no errors are found, the M-phase follows. This is where mitosis begins.

pageData.altText: Figure 3: The different stages of a cell cycle.
pageData.desc: Figure 3: The different stages of a cell cycle.

pageData.text: The process of replication is aided by , or . RNA is similar to DNA but differs in several important ways. RNA contains ribose, whereas DNA contains deoxyribose. As mentioned previously, eukaryotic DNA is double stranded, in the form of a helix, whereas RNA is single stranded. Furthermore, the nitrogenous base , which is found in DNA, is replaced with (U) in RNA strands. Uracil pairs with .

For replication to begin in the eukaryotic cell, the DNA molecule must unwind into two single-stranded templates that will serve as the sequential patterns for the new replica strands of . Enzymes, called , nick the strand and provide an opening for unwinding to occur at hundreds of points along the chromosome, called . Another enzyme present in the nuclear material, , unwinds the double helix by breaking the hydrogen bonds between nitrogenous bases. Binding proteins attach to the “unzipped” strands to keep them from rebinding.

Both nucleotide chains serve as templates for , but they are not processed the same way. Recall that the strands are antiparallel. The strand that is oriented in the 5’ to 3’ direction is called the . The strand oriented in the 3’ to 5’ direction is called the .

The DNA polymerase enzymes that assist in synthesizing the new DNA strand only make DNA in the 5’ to 3’ direction. For the leading strand, an enzyme complex with DNA polymerase adds complementary nucleotides to the template strand in the 5’ to 3’ direction and continues to do so as the double strands unzip.

For the lagging strand, DNA synthesis is more complicated. DNA polymerase cannot initiate DNA synthesis without a phosphate to bind to; however, RNA polymerase can. Primase initiates the addition of the first RNA, and RNA polymerase adds about 10 RNA bases to the exposed 3’ portion of the lagging strand. This RNA portion is called a . DNA polymerase then takes over, adding DNA bases following the primer.

Replication on the lagging strand occurs in short, discontinuous segments in the opposite direction of the leading strand. Continuous addition of RNA primers and short DNA segments of the lagging strand are required to keep pace with the synthesis of the leading strand. Thus, only a limited stretch of DNA (an , named for its discoverer) can be synthesized from the lagging strand at one time.

RNA primer segments must be excised, as they are not suitable long-term substitutes for DNA nucleotides in the genetic code. The phosphate bonds between the DNA sugar and the RNA sugar are broken to remove the RNA primer, and DNA polymerase brings in the DNA nucleotides that add on at the 3’ end of the preceding sugar to fill the gap. During DNA replication, polymerization begins at the open 3’ end of the nucleotide chain.

To summarize <button class='glossary-text'>DNA replication</button>, the two strands of DNA separate. Each strand serves as a template to which new complementary bases are added. A host of enzymes, principally DNA polymerases, add <button class='glossary-text'>nucleotides</button> to the template following base pairing rules, resulting in two newly synthesized strands of DNA, each bound to the original template.

pageData.subTitle: Transcription
pageData.text: RNA is the vehicle through which the genetic code is translated into the proteins that perform all of life’s functions. An RNA nucleotide, like a DNA nucleotide, contains inorganic phosphate group(s), a sugar, and a nitrogenous base. However, the sugar in RNA is ribose, and the nitrogenous base does not occur. Instead, is complemented by in RNA. RNA molecules are able to bind together to make long strands. The order of nucleotides in an RNA sequence is determined by the order of nucleotides in DNA. Enzymes in the cell are able to read the order of nucleotides in the DNA and match complementary RNA bases to the DNA sequence. This process is called .

pageData.altText: Figure 4: An illustration of RNA transcription.
pageData.desc: Figure 4: An illustration of RNA transcription.

pageData.text: begins in a process called when RNA polymerase binds to a site with a specific DNA sequence, called a . In eukaryotic cells, other molecules, called “transcription factors,” also play a role in initiating the process of RNA synthesis. Once RNA polymerase binds to the DNA, the double strand is unwound and separated.

<button class='glossary-text'>Elongation</button> occurs next, where the enzyme travels along one of the DNA strands, called the template, or antisense strand, in the 3’ to 5’ direction. As it travels, the enzyme reads the DNA sequence and builds a complementary strand of RNA. This RNA strand is generated from 5’ to 3’.
The RNA polymerase eventually falls off in a process called , where the two DNA strands reconnect, and the complementary RNA sequence is free within the nucleus.
There are three major types of RNA generated by transcription: ribosomal (rRNA), messenger (mRNA), and transfer (tRNA).

Ribosomal RNA combines with proteins to form complexes called . Each ribosome has two sites: amino acyl (A site) and peptidyl (P site). The ribosome functions in stabilizing and moving various members of the protein synthesis apparatus at appropriate times within the cytoplasm. Messenger RNA provides the instructions for protein synthesis based on the DNA sequence.

pageData.altText: Figure 5: Illustration of the activation of tRNA.
pageData.desc: Figure 5: Illustration of the activation of tRNA.

pageData.text: Process_of_transcription.jpg by NHS National Genetics and Genomics Education Centre is available under CC BY 2.0 at https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Process_of_transcription_%2813080846733%29.jpg

Transfer RNA interacts with <button class='glossary-text'>ribosomes</button> and acts as a carrier molecule, transferring specific amino acids designated by the mRNA sequences to an amino acid chain. The tRNA folds in such a way that its anticodon (3’ <button class='glossary-text'>nucleotide</button> sequence) can bind with a complementary codon on the mRNA. At the 3’ end of the tRNA sequence, there is a site for a specific amino acid to bind.

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes the stages of transcription?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Transcription goes through the stages of initiation (RNA polymerase binds to the DNA), elongation (RNA polymerase reads and DNA and synthesis an RNA sequence), and termination (RNA polymerase releases the DNA and the new RNA molecule is complete).

pageData.question: What is one way that DNA is different from RNA?

options.text: DNA has thymine and RNA has uracil.
DNA has ribose and RNA has deoxyribose.
DNA has more enzymes than RNA.
DNA has adenine-thymine base pairing and RNA has adenine-adenine base pairing.
DNA is synthesized on the leading strand and RNA is synthesized on the lagging strand.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: DNA has the nucleotide thymine (T), which is not found in RNA. RNA has the nucleotide uracil (U), which is not found in DNA.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: An RNA nucleotide, like a DNA nucleotide, contains inorganic phosphate group(s), sugar, and a nitrogenous base. However, the sugar in RNA is ribose, and the nitrogenous base thymine does not occur. Instead, adenine is complemented by uracil in RNA. RNA molecules can bind together to make long strands. The order of nucleotides in an RNA sequence is determined by the order of nucleotides in DNA. Enzymes in the cell can read the order of nucleotides in the DNA and match complementary RNA bases to the DNA sequence. This process is called transcription, which consists of three stages: initiation (when RNA polymerase binds to the DNA and separates its strands), elongation (when RNA polymerase reads the DNA sequence and builds a complimentary strand of RNA), and termination (when RNA polymerase falls off the DNA, its strands reconnect, and the new RNA is free within the nucleus).

img.alt: Figure 4: An illustration of RNA transcription.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: An RNA nucleotide, like a DNA nucleotide, contains inorganic phosphate group(s), sugar, and a nitrogenous base. However, the sugar in RNA is ribose, and the nitrogenous base thymine does not occur. Instead, adenine is complemented by uracil in RNA. RNA molecules can bind together to make long strands. The order of nucleotides in an RNA sequence is determined by the order of nucleotides in DNA. Enzymes in the cell can read the order of nucleotides in the DNA and match complementary RNA bases to the DNA sequence. This process is called transcription, which consists of three stages: initiation (when RNA polymerase binds to the DNA and separates its strands), elongation (when RNA polymerase reads the DNA sequence and builds a complimentary strand of RNA), and termination (when RNA polymerase falls off the DNA, its strands reconnect, and the new RNA is free within the nucleus).

img.alt: Figure 4: An illustration of RNA transcription.

pageData.subTitle: Translation and Protein Synthesis
pageData.text: Messenger RNA and transfer RNA work together to position amino acids at the <button class='glossary-text'>ribosome</button> for protein synthesis. The specific order of amino acids is determined by the mRNA codons; thus, the genetic code is translated into a sequence of amino acids during protein synthesis. The ribosomes take residence in the cell’s cytoplasm and function as sites for protein synthesis. Eukaryotic ribosomes have two parts, a small and a large subunit. The small subunit is referred to as 40 S, and the large subunit is referred to as 60 S.

The ribosomes function to stabilize and move various molecules necessary for protein synthesis at appropriate times within the cytoplasm. They also catalyze the formation of peptide bonds between amino acids to create a polypeptide chain, the primary structure of a protein.

Transfer RNA is found throughout the cytoplasm, where it reacts with activated amino acids. Activation consists of an enzyme-mediated reaction between an amino acid and ATP. The enzymes involved in this reaction recognize specific amino acids and specific tRNA molecules. For example, the activating enzyme for glycine will bind glycine only to glycine-specific tRNA molecules. The amino acid-tRNA complex reaches a ribosome by diffusion. The tRNA binds to a single amino acid that enters the aminoacyl site. If the single amino acid is a match with the <button class='glossary-text'>nucleotides</button> in the mRNA strand, then the tRNA binds to the aminoacyl site. If the three nucleotides are not complementary, the tRNA is rejected.

Activation of the tRNA occurs when an enzyme called aminoacyl-tRNA synthase brings the free-floating amino acid and tRNA together. With energy input from ATP, the amino acid binds to the tRNA. At this point, the tRNA is considered to be red to be activated.

As the mRNA sequence passes through the ribosomal subunits, one codon (3 <button class='glossary-text'>nucleotides</button>) is read at the aminoacyl-tRNA site (A site). This codon interacts with free-floating tRNAs. When the anti-codon of the specific tRNA complements the mRNA codon, then the tRNA is transferred to the peptidyl-tRNA site (P site) and the associated amino acid is added to the chain to build a polypeptide or protein. Energy is required for many of the reactions, and it is provided by the hydrolysis of GTP, a molecule similar to ATP.

When this sequence is translated into a protein, a matching amino acid is selected for each codon in the sequence. The codons do not start at a random site; the first mRNA codon is always AUG, or the amino acid methionine. Once the “Start” (AUG) codon is located, the rest of the codons will follow, three nucleotides at a time. This process is known as . Each of these codons specifies a single amino acid. The meaning of each codon is known and can be seen in the table below. Note that most amino acids have more than one codon. This helps to safeguard against DNA mutations. There are also one start codon and three stop codons present.

Once the initiator-tRNA anticodon binds to the complementary mRNA sequence in the P-site, initiation factors help the large ribosomal subunit attach to the complex. The initial methionine is located on one end of the polypeptide, which is called the N-terminus. The opposite end of the polypeptide is called the C-terminus.

If there is a tRNA already in the P-site, its amino acid chain is transferred to the end of the amino acid in the A-site. A peptide bond is formed by a reaction catalyzed by the large subunit of the . Next, the ribosome moves the tRNA from the A-site to the P-site. The former P-site tRNA is released from the ribosome without its amino acid. The ribosome moves the mRNA so that a new codon is above the A-site. This process is known as .

<button class='glossary-text'>Translation</button> is <button class='glossary-text'>terminated</button> when the mRNA stop sequence moves into the A-site. A protein called a release factor binds in the place of a tRNA and breaks the bond between the tRNA and the polypeptide. Finally, the ribosomal subunits separate and the polypeptide is freed. There are three “stop” codons, which are the combinations of <button class='glossary-text'>nucleotides</button> that signal the replication enzymes to halt (Figure 6).

pageData.altText: Figure 6: Three stop codons terminating translation.
pageData.desc: Figure 6: Three stop codons terminating translation.

pageData.subTitle: Mutations
pageData.text: With advancements in biotechnology, scientists now rely on DNA similarities to determine relationships between groups of organisms. Species that have similar DNA sequences are thought to have evolved from a common ancestor.

Organisms that are more distantly related have, over time, accumulated more differences in their DNA sequences. The difference between DNA sequences, both within a species and across species, is called . The mechanism of variation is mutation, a change in DNA sequence. Harmful mutations that hinder an organism’s fitness (its ability to survive and reproduce) are less likely to be passed on to the next generation.

Mutations that generate advantages for an organism may be selected for by natural selection, the driving force of evolution. Many types of mutations exist, including (s), , , and gene duplications. A point mutation is the replacement of one base with another. This can sometimes lead to having one amino acid replaced with another, which can lead to a nonfunctional protein or a protein with completely different characteristics. As an example, when a DNA sequence has ACG, this will translate to a cystine amino acid. Should a point mutation change this sequence to ACT, this now stands for a stop codon, and protein synthesis will stop after this codon, leading to an incomplete and nonfunctional protein. Insertion occurs when nucleotides are added into a DNA sequence. Deletion occurs when nucleotides are omitted from a DNA sequence.

Mutations can occur because of mistakes during or as a result of environmental influences, such as UV radiation or chemical exposure. Scientists do not understand all of the factors that influence the rate of mutation. However, it is known that because of the redundancy of the genetic code, not all mutations result in a phenotypic change; these unexpressed mutations are called . Multiple combinations of RNA code for the same amino acid. If a point mutation occurs but the resulting codon codes for the same amino acid during , the protein will likely function properly. A mutation that causes one amino acid in the protein sequence to change is referred to as a . A mutation that leads to a stop signal in an inappropriate place is called a . If the translational enzymes are signaled to stop before the protein is complete, the protein is unlikely to function at all. There may be other variables that affect the success of protein synthesis, such as post-translational modifications, but these are beyond the scope of this discussion.

pageData.altText: Figure 7: An illustration of examples of different types of mutations; a mutagenic event, a deletion, an insertion, and a substitution.
pageData.desc: Figure 7: An illustration of examples of different types of mutations; a mutagenic event, a deletion, an insertion, and a substitution.

pageData.question: A substitution mutation occurs in a gene, but the resulting codon codes for the same amino acid as the original codon. Which of the following best describes how this mutation impacts the protein synthesized from this mutated gene?

options.text: The protein would most likely function properly.
The protein would most likely be duplicated.
The protein would most likely be larger.
The protein would most likely not be translated.
The protein would most likely have a new function.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: If a substitution mutation occurs but the resulting codon codes for the same amino acid during translation, the protein will likely function properly.

pageData.question: Which of the following is true about mutation?

options.text: A mutation does not necessarily result in a phenotypic change.
A mutation results in a phenotypic change.
Mutations are always caused by misfolded proteins.
Mutations do not affect start and stop codons.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Because of the redundancy of the genetic code, not all mutations result in a phenotypic change; these unexpressed mutations are called silent mutations.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Species that have similar DNA sequences are thought to have evolved from a common ancestor. Organisms that are more distantly related have, over time, accumulated more differences in their DNA sequences. The difference between DNA sequences, both within a species and across species, is called genetic variation. Mutations that generate advantages for an organism may be selected by natural selection, the driving force of evolution. Many types of mutations exist, including substitutions, insertions, deletions, and gene duplications. A mutation that causes one amino acid in the protein sequence to change is referred to as a missense mutation. A mutation that leads to a stop signal in an inappropriate place is called a nonsense mutation. If a point mutation occurs but the resulting codon codes for the same amino acid during translation, the protein will likely function properly.

img.alt: Figure 7: An illustration of examples of different types of mutations; a mutagenic event, a deletion, an insertion, and a substitution.

pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow of Activities 1-3 of the investigation. Before beginning the investigation, you will open the DNA to Protein Lab Interactive. In activity 1, you will observe the simulations of transcription and translation. In activity 2, you will derive the mRNA sequence from a given amino acid sequence, then determine the DNA sense strand from the mRNA sequence. Next, you will confirm the sequences using the lab interactive. This activity is repeated until 10 different amino acid sequences are completed. In activity 3, you will record the original DNA and amino acid sequences before editing the DNA sequence according to a given change. Then, you will simulate transcription and translation of the edited DNA and compare the new amino acid sequence to the original sequence. Finally, reset the interactive. This process of editing the DNA and observing the changes is repeated until 10 DNA changes are completed. Continue to activity 4.

A map describing the procedural workflow of Activities 4-5 of the investigation. After completing activity 3, in activity 4, you will edit the DNA sequence with a point substitution, then simulate transcription and translation of the edited DNA. Next, you will compare the amino acid sequence to the original sequence and reset the lab interactive. This activity is repeated until 10 mutations are observed. In activity 5, you will delete 1 base pair in the DNA sequence, and simulate transcription and translation of the edited DNA. Next, compare the amino acid sequence to the original sequence. Finally, design a hydrophilic protein and a protein with a hydrophobic head.

text: Internet connection
Camera or cellphone capable of taking pictures

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes the product of transcription?

options.text: tRNA works with mRNA to position amino acids at the ribosome for protein synthesis.
tRNA transfers code from DNA to proteins.
tRNA forms part of the structure of the large ribosomal subunit.
tRNA provides the instructions for protein synthesis based on a DNA sequence.
tRNA builds a complementary strand of DNA.

assestmentData.question: What type of mutagenic event is most likely to cause a missense mutation?

options.text: an error in translation during protein synthesis

Go to: http://lab.concord.org/embeddable.html#interactives/sam/DNA-to-proteins/1-dna-to-protein.json
In Activity 1, you will use an interactive website to observe and identify the steps of and .
Click the “Transcribe” button and watch how DNA is transcribed into mRNA.
Hit the "Reset" button before starting the next steps.

Closely examine all the steps of the <button class='glossary-text'>transcription</button> by clicking the “Transcribe step by step” button. After each step, click this button again to proceed to the next step.
Note which RNA nitrogenous base pairs up with which DNA nitrogenous base.
After transcription is complete, click on the  “Translate” button to see how a full protein is generated from mRNA.
Hit the "Reset" button before starting the next steps.

Closely examine all the steps of the <button class='glossary-text'>translation</button> by clicking the “Translate step by step” button; after each step, click this button again to proceed to the next step.
Note which codon stands for which amino acids; use Table 1 to see the mRNA codon for each of the amino acids.

pageData.title: Table 1: mRNA Codons for Amino Acids

pageData.text: Examine the protein strand closely. Click on each of the amino acids to see their properties and if the hydrophobic or hydrophilic characterstics have changed.
Repeat a complete transcription and translation a few times and note which amino acid comes from which DNA codon.

In Activity 2, you will determine all possible mRNA sequences that could be translated into specified amino acid sequences. Then, you will check your work by creating these mRNA and amino acid sequences in the interactive website.

typeBefore.text: This activity utilizes the interactive’s “Edit DNA” feature on the webpage. When clicked, it shows the original sequence which is the sense strand of the DNA (the top strand of the DNA on the webpage, see Figure 8).

typeBefore.altText: Figure 8: A screenshot from the DNA to Protein Lab Interactive. Two horizontal, complementary strands of DNA are separated from each other. The top strand is labeled DNA sense strand. The bottom strand is labeled DNA anti-sense strand. A shorter mRNA strand is bonded and complementary to the bottom DNA strand.
typeBefore.desc: A screenshot from the DNA to Protein Lab Interactive. Two horizontal, complementary strands of DNA are separated from each other. The top strand is labeled DNA sense strand. The bottom strand is labeled DNA anti-sense strand. A shorter mRNA strand is bonded and complementary to the bottom DNA strand.

pageData.text: Click the “Transcribe” button and watch how DNA is transcribed into mRNA.

Use the mRNA codon chart in Table 1 to write down the mRNA sequence that would translate into each of the following amino acid sequences. If more than one codon can be used for an amino acid, please list all possibilities. Record the mRNA sequences in the Lab Notebook.

text: met-ser-leu-gly-trp-stop
met-ser-pro-cys-his-stop
met-ile-asn-ala-tyr-stop
met-gln-thr-leu-arg-cys-pro-lys-stop
start-ile-glu-asp-ser-his-trp-stop
start-leu-pro-gln-tyr-ile-met-val-ala-stop
start-ala-glu-trp-ser-phe-pro-ser-gly-thr-stop
start-val-ala-thr-thr-leu-tyr-cys-gly-arg-stop
start-lys-asn-gly-phe-his-thr-arg-pro-gln-stop
start-met-thr-asn-lys-pro-gln-ser-leu-arg-stop

pageData.text: Write down the DNA sense strand for each mRNA sequence. The sense strand (see Figure 8) is not complementary to the mRNA strand, but rather is similar to the mRNA sequence with the exception of (U). Record the DNA sequences in the Lab Notebook.
Double check your work by translating each of your mRNA sequences using the digital model.

pageData.title: Table 1: mRNA Codons for Amino Acids

pageData.text: In Activity 3, you will use the interactive website to modify the original DNA sequence with specified changes and observe the resulting amino acid sequences.

typeBefore.text: This activity utilizes the interactive’s “Edit DNA” feature on the webpage. When clicked, it shows the original sequence which is the sense strand of the DNA (the top strand of the DNA on the webpage, see ).

pageData.text: Click the "Reset" button on the interactive if it is not already at the start.
Click the "Edit DNA" button and record the  original sequence in the Lab Notebook.

Click the "Start/continue model" button to observe the <button class='glossary-text'>transcription</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>translation</button> of the DNA sequence, Record the amino acid sequence as the original amino acid sequence in the Lab Notebook. You can use the "Stop" button to pause the interactive while you record this sequence.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Take a photograph or screenshot of the detached protein in the interactive.
Reset the interactive.
For each DNA change, complete the following steps.

text: Click the "Edit DNA" button to make the change described.
Copy the edited DNA sequence into the Lab Notebook.
Start the model to transcribe and translate the edited DNA.
Record the new amino acid sequence in the Lab Notebook.

pageData.text: Take a photograph or screenshot of the detached protein in the interactive.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

text: 1. Reset the interactive.

pageData.text: Perform the activity using the following DNA  changes:

text: Change the fifth DNA codon to TGA.
Change the first codon to TGA.
Change the second codon to TAG.
Change the last codon to TTG.
Change the third codon to ATG.
Switch the first and the last codon.
Switch the seventh and first codon.
Switch the seventh and last codon.
Switch the ninth codon with the second codon.
Completely reverse the sequence, thus placing the first codon last, second codon before that, etc.

pageData.text: In Activity 4, you will use the interactive website to model 10 different <button class='glossary-text'>substitution</button> mutations of your choice and observe the resulting changes in the amino acid sequences.

typeBefore.text: This activity utilizes the interactive’s “Edit DNA” feature on the webpage. When clicked, it shows the original sequence which is the sense strand of the DNA (the top strand of the DNA on the webpage, see ).

pageData.text: Use the "Edit DNA" feature of the interactive to simulate 10 different <button class='glossary-text'>substitution</button> mutations in the DNA sequence. Each substitution should only be 1 nucleotide long.
Answer the questions in the Lab Notebook.
In Activity 5, you will use the interactive website to model a <button class='glossary-text'>deletion</button> mutation. Then, you will design proteins with hydrophilic and hydrophobic properties.

typeBefore.text: This activity utilizes the interactive’s “Edit DNA” feature on the webpage. When clicked, it shows the original sequence which is the sense strand of the DNA (the top strand of the DNA on the webpage, see ).

pageData.text: Click the "Reset" button on the interactive if it is not already at the start.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Randomly delete one nitrogen base from the original DNA sequence. Copy this edited DNA sequence into the Lab Notebook.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Design a protein product that consists of mainly hydrophilic amino acids. (represented with a green color in the digital model). Take a photograph or screenshot of the detached protein in the interactive.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: For a protein to be exported out of the cell, the head needs to be hydrophobic. Design a protein with a hydrophobic head of at least four amino acids. Take a photograph or screenshot of the detached protein in the interactive.
You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: A diagram of a DNA molecule shows two strands twisted around each other. Each strand is an alternating sequence of sugars and phosphate groups, with a base attached to each sugar. The bases orient toward each other and form specific pairs. A pairs with T, and G pairs with C.

Figure 2: Deoxyribose is a five-membered ring. One oxygen atom and four carbon atoms make up the ring. The carbon atoms are numbered clockwise from the oxygen atom. Carbons one prime, two prime, three prime, and four prime make up the rest of the ring. Carbon five prime extends from carbon four prime, and is not part of the ring. Each carbon atom, except for carbon two prime, has an attached O H group.
Figure 3: The different stages of a cell cycle.
Figure 4: An illustration of RNA transcription.
Figure 5: Illustration of the activation of tRNA.
Figure 6: Three stop codons terminating translation.
Figure 7: An illustration of examples of different types of mutations; a mutagenic event, a deletion, an insertion, and a substitution.

A map describing the procedural workflow of Activities 1-3 of the investigation. Before beginning the investigation, you will open the DNA to Protein Lab Interactive. In activity 1, you will observe the simulations of transcription and translation. In activity 2, you will derive the mRNA sequence from a given amino acid sequence, then determine the DNA sense strand from the mRNA sequence. Next, you will confirm the sequences using the lab interactive. This activity is repeated until 10 different amino acid sequences are completed. In activity 3, you will record the original DNA and amino acid sequences before editing the DNA sequence according to a given change. Then, you will simulate transcription and translation of the edited DNA and compare the new amino acid sequence to the original sequence. Finally, reset the interactive. This process of editing the DNA and observing the changes is repeated until 10 DNA changes are completed. Continue to activity 4.

A map describing the procedural workflow of Activities 4-5 of the investigation. After completing activity 3, in activity 4, you will edit the DNA sequence with a point substitution, then simulate transcription and translation of the edited DNA. Next, you will compare the amino acid sequence to the original sequence and reset the lab interactive. This activity is repeated until 10 mutations are observed. In activity 5, you will delete 1 base pair in the DNA sequence, and simulate transcription and translation of the edited DNA. Next, compare the amino acid sequence to the original sequence. Finally, design a hydrophilic protein and a protein with a hydrophobic head.

pageData.altText: Figure 8: A screenshot from the DNA to Protein Lab Interactive. Two horizontal, complementary strands of DNA are separated from each other. The top strand is labeled DNA sense strand. The bottom strand is labeled DNA anti-sense strand. A shorter mRNA strand is bonded and complementary to the bottom DNA strand.

data.title: Adenine (A)
data.content: One of the five nitrogenous bases of nucleic acids; it is classified as a purine and it pairs with thymine (T) in DNA and uracil (U) in RNA

data.title: Cytosine (C)
data.content: One of the five nitrogenous bases of nucleic acids; it is classified as a pyrimidine and it pairs with guanine (G)

data.title: Deletion
data.content: A type of mutation that occurs when nucleotides are omitted from a DNA sequence

data.title: Deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA)
data.content: A type of nucleic acid made up of nucleotide monomers containing deoxyribose sugar; it stores the genetic information of an organism

data.title: DNA helicase
data.content: An enzyme that partly denatures (separates) DNA's double strand during DNA replication

data.title: DNA replication
data.content: The process of duplicating DNA during cell division

data.title: Duplication
data.content: A mutation in which one or more copies of a DNA segment is produced; it can be as small as just a few bases or as large as a major chromosomal region

data.title: Elongation
data.content: The process of an enzyme reading a DNA sequence and building a complementary strand of RNA during transcription; it is also the process of a ribosome reading an mRNA sequence and building a complementary sequence of amino acids during translation

data.title: Endonuclease
data.content: An enzyme which cleaves the hydrogen bonds of a polynucleotide chain which provides an opening for unwinding of the molecule to occur

data.title: Gene
data.content: A specific sequence of nucleotides, the order of which determines the amino acid sequence of a protein.

data.title: Genetic variation
data.content: Differences between DNA sequences within a species and across species

data.title: Guanine (G)
data.content: One of the five nitrogenous bases of nucleic acids; it is classified as a purine and pairs with cytosine (C)

data.title: Initiation
data.content: The process of RNA polymerase binding to a site with a specific DNA sequence to start transcription; also the process of a ribosome identifying and binding to the AUG codon of an mRNA strand to start translation

data.title: Insertion
data.content: A mutation in which nucleotides are added into a DNA sequence

data.title: Lagging strand
data.content: During DNA replication it is the strand that is oriented in the 3' to 5' direction

data.title: Leading strand
data.content: During DNA replication it is the strand that is oriented in the 5' to 3' direction

data.title: Missense mutation
data.content: A mutation in which one amino acid in the protein sequence is changed to a different amino acid

data.title: Mitosis
data.content: The phase of the cell cycle during which actual cell division takes place; it gives rise to genetically identical cells in which the total number of chromosomes is maintained; also called M phase

data.title: Nonsense mutation
data.content: A mutation that leads to a stop signal in an inappropriate place in the mRNA sequence

data.title: Nucleotide
data.content: The monomer of nucleic acids; it consists of a pentose (five-carbon) sugar, a phosphate group, and a nitrogenous base

data.title: Okazaki fragment
data.content: Short sections of DNA formed because of discontinuous synthesis of the lagging strand during DNA replication

data.title: Primer
data.content: A short nucleic acid sequence that provides a starting point for nucleic acid synthesis

data.title: Promoter
data.content: A region of DNA upstream of a gene where relevant proteins bind to initiate transcription

data.title: Replication fork
data.content: A region where the double helix has been unwound and separated, and DNA replication occurs

data.title: Ribonucleic acid (RNA)
data.content: A type of nucleic acid that is single-stranded and involved in protein synthesis; it is made up nucleotide monomers containing ribose sugar

data.title: Ribosome
data.content: A complex molecular machine that translates mRNA molecules to produce polypeptides (amino acid sequences)

data.title: Silent mutation
data.content: A mutation that does not result in a phenotypic change in the organism

data.title: Substitution
data.content: A mutation in which one nucleotide base is replaced with another nucleotide base

data.title: Termination
data.content: The process of RNA polymerase falling off a DNA molecule at the end of transcription, allowing the two DNA strands reconnect, and the complementary RNA sequence to be free within the nucleus; it is also the process of a ribosome falling off an mRNA strand and the amino acid sequence becoming free within the cell

data.title: Thymine (T)
data.content: One of the five nitrogenous bases of nucleic acids, but is found only in DNA; it is classified as a pyrimidine and pairs with adenine (A)

data.title: Transcription
data.content: The process of synthesizing an mRNA sequence complementary to a DNA sequence for the purpose of synthesizing proteins

data.title: Translation
data.content: The process of reading an mRNA sequence to synthesize an amino acid sequence, and ultimately a protein

data.title: Uracil (U)
data.content: One of the five nitrogenous bases of nucleic acids, but is found only in RNA; it is classified as a pyrimidine and pairs with adenine (A)
